bounce.translation[0].definitions[0].def: if a ball or other object bounces, or you bounce it, it immediately moves up or away from a surface after hitting it
bounce.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: The ball bounced off the post and into the goal.
The kids were bouncing a ball against the wall.
bounce.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to move up and down, especially because you are hitting a surface that is made of rubber, has springs etc
bounce.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: Stop bouncing up and down on the sofa.
Lyn was bouncing on the trampoline.
bounce.translation[0].definitions[2].def: if a cheque bounces, or if a bank bounces a cheque, the bank will not pay any money because there is not enough money in the account of the person who wrote it
bounce.translation[0].definitions[3].def: to walk quickly and with a lot of energy
bounce.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: Olivia came bouncing into the room.
bounce.translation[0].definitions[4].def: if something bounces, it moves quickly up and down as you move
bounce.translation[0].definitions[4].exa: Her hair bounced when she walked.
bounce.translation[0].definitions[5].def: if light or sound bounces, it hits a surface and then moves quickly away from it
bounce.translation[0].definitions[5].exa: The radio signals are bounced off a satellite.
bounce.translation[0].definitions[6].def: if an email that you send bounces or is bounced, it is returned to you and the other person does not receive it because of a technical problem
bounce.translation[0].definitions[7].def: to force someone to leave a place, job, or organization, especially because they have done something wrong
bounce.translation[0].definitions[7].exa: Taylor was bounced from the team for assaulting another player.
bounce.translation[1].definitions[0].def: the action of moving up and down on a surface
bounce.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: Try to catch the ball on the second bounce.
bounce.translation[1].definitions[1].def: the ability to move up and down on a surface, or that surface’s ability to make something move up and down
bounce.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: The ball had completely lost its bounce.
a basketball court with good bounce
bounce.translation[1].definitions[2].def: a lot of energy that someone has
bounce.translation[1].definitions[2].exa: Exercise is great. I feel like there’s a new bounce in my step.
bounce.translation[1].definitions[3].def: hair that has bounce is in very good condition and goes back to its shape if you press it
bounce.translation[1].definitions[3].exa: a brand-new styling spray that gives your hair body and bounce
bounce.translation[1].definitions[4].def: a sudden increase in something such as how popular a leader is
bounce.translation[1].definitions[4].exa: the bounce in the property market
bounce.translation[2].definitions[0].def: if a cheque bounces or a bank bounces it, the bank will not pay any money because there is not enough money in the account of the person who wrote the cheque
bounce.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: Every time a cheque bounces it costs us £25 in bank charges.
His bank bounced the cheque and cancelled his overdraft.
bounce.translation[2].definitions[1].def: to quickly increase in price or amount, especially after having fallen
bounce.translation[2].definitions[1].exa: The airline’s shares bounced to 617p before settling back to 604p.
bounce.translation[2].definitions[2].def: if a stockmarket bounces, it suddenly becomes very active and share prices rise
bounce.translation[2].definitions[2].exa: Tokyo’s beleaguered stock market bounced dramatically to erase some of its recent losses.
bounce.translation[2].definitions[3].def: if an email that you send bounces or is bounced back, it is returned to you and the other person does not receive it because of a technical problem
bounce.translation[3].definitions[0].def: a sudden rise in something such as prices, sales, or share prices
bounce.translation[3].definitions[0].exa: Economists agree that there could be a bounce in prices next year.
